question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It was / the very well-directed film / and we enjoyed it.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 11 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM) (2))
solution:
Error Explanation:
The error is in the article usage before the phrase "very well-directed film."

  • Article: The definite article "the" is incorrect in this context.

  • The correct article should be "a", because the sentence is referring to one film in a general context, not a specific one already known.

‚úÖ Correct form: "It was a very well-directed film, and we enjoyed it."

So, the part of speech with the error is the article ‚Äî incorrect usage of "the" instead of "a."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The platinum is a precious metal.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 11_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: (1) The platinum
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The word "platinum" is a non-countable noun referring to a type of metal, so it should not be preceded by the definite article "The" unless specifying a particular sample.
‚Ä¢ The correct sentence is: "Platinum is a precious metal."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A music / is a great way / to express / your emotions.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 11_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (3) A music
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The word "music" is an uncountable noun and should not be preceded by the article "a."
‚Ä¢ The correct phrase is simply "Music is a great way..." without "a."
‚Ä¢ Other parts of the sentence are correct.
‚Ä¢ Therefore, segment (3) contains the grammatical error.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Antique diamond necklace / was stolen / from the museum.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence is:

‚ÄúAntique diamond necklace / was stolen / from the museum.‚Äù

Let‚Äôs examine the subject:

  • ‚ÄúAntique diamond necklace‚Äù is a singular countable noun, and in English, singular countable nouns usually require an article (like ‚Äúan‚Äù or ‚Äúthe‚Äù) before them.

üî¥ Missing article: It should be ‚ÄúAn antique diamond necklace‚Äù, not just ‚ÄúAntique diamond necklace.‚Äù

‚úîÔ∏è Correct Sentence:

An antique diamond necklace was stolen from the museum.

üõ†Ô∏è Part of Speech with the Error:

Article usage ‚Äî Missing article ‚ÄúAn‚Äù before a singular countable noun

‚úÖ Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is:Antique diamond necklace.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This is / too grave sin / to be / pardoned.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

‚ùå What's wrong?

  • The phrase ‚Äútoo grave sin‚Äù is grammatically incorrect.

  • In English, when using an adjective like ‚Äúgrave‚Äù before a singular countable noun like ‚Äúsin,‚Äù an article is required.

  • Also, ‚Äútoo grave‚Äù should be ‚Äútoo grave a sin‚Äù ‚Äî this is a common structure in English.

‚úÖ Correct usage:

  • "too + adjective + a + singular countable noun"

üî∏ Example: It was too difficult a question to answer.
üî∏ So here: ‚Äútoo grave a sin to be pardoned‚Äù ‚úÖ

Part of Speech with the Error:

Article usage ‚Äî missing ‚Äúa‚Äù before the singular noun ‚Äúsin‚Äù

‚úîÔ∏è Correct Sentence:

This is too grave a sin to be pardoned.

‚úÖ Therefore, the segment with the grammatical error is: too grave sin.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Don‚Äôt let the failure / demotivate you as / failures are the / stepping stones to success.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: "Don‚Äôt let the failure"

The correction "Don‚Äôt let failure" is appropriate because, in this context, the word "failure" is used in a more general sense to refer to the concept of experiencing failure, rather than a specific instance of failure. When using "failure" in a broad, abstract way, we often omit the definite article "the."

The corrected sentence would be: "Don‚Äôt let failure" (without "the").

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I love the dogs /; but I don‚Äôt like / the dog my friend Tinzie / owns since it bites people.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
option_1: owns since it bites people
option_2: ; but I don‚Äôt like
option_4: the dog my friend Tinzie
solution:
Answer: c) I love the dogs

Explanation:
The error lies in the use of the definite article ‚Äúthe‚Äù in ‚ÄúI love the dogs.‚Äù

  • The sentence is expressing a general liking for dogs, not referring to any specific group of dogs.

  • In English, when talking about things in general, we do not use "the" before plural countable nouns like "dogs."

‚úî So, the correct phrase should be:
‚ÄúI love dogs‚Äù ‚Äî to indicate a general preference.

Why other parts are correct:

  • ‚Äú; but I don‚Äôt like‚Äù ‚Äì correct contrast structure using a semicolon.

  • ‚Äúthe dog my friend Tinzie‚Äù ‚Äì would be correct when completed with ‚Äúowns‚Äù (which it is in the next segment).

  • ‚Äúowns since it bites people‚Äù ‚Äì grammatically fine; ‚Äúsince‚Äù is used correctly as ‚Äúbecause.‚Äù

Hence, option (c) contains the grammatical error due to the unnecessary use of "the".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error and select the option which rectifies that error.
The SNAP-10 A / was launched on 3 April 1965 / on a Atlas-Agena D rocket / from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-1)
option_1: at Vandenberg Air Force Base.
option_3: on an Atlas-Agena D rocket
solution:
The segment containing the grammatical error is: "on a Atlas-Agena D rocket".

on a Atlas-Agena D rocket: This segment contains a grammatical error. The article "a" should be "an" because "Atlas-Agena" starts with a vowel sound. In English, the indefinite article "a" is used before words that begin with a consonant sound, and "an" is used before words that begin with a vowel sound.

Thus, the corrected sentence should be:

"The SNAP-10 A was launched on 3 April 1965 on an Atlas-Agena D rocket from Vandenberg Air Force Base."

question:
Choose the sentence that contains an error.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: He is chef who specialises in Italian cuisine.
option_2: She is the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.
option_3: The Earth revolves around the Sun.
option_4: I love the taste of fresh strawberries in the summer.
solution:
The sentence that contains an error is: "He is chef who specialises in Italian cuisine."

The corrected version should be: "He is a chef who specializes in Italian cuisine."

Explanation: The original sentence lacks the article "a" before "chef."

The correct usage is "a chef" because "chef" is a singular countable noun.

Additionally, "specialises" should be spelled as "specializes" in American English.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Henry is known / as an excellent writer / and good communicator / in English.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 12_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: and good communicator

The corrected sentence should be: "Henry is known as an excellent writer and a good communicator in English."

The error in the original sentence lies in the lack of parallel structure. In a series of items connected by "and," it is important to maintain parallelism, meaning that similar grammatical structures should be used for each item in the series.

The corrected sentence introduces parallel structure by adding "a" before "good communicator," making both descriptions ("an excellent writer" and "a good communicator") parallel. This creates a grammatically correct and balanced sentence.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
There is a very little time / for them to prepare / for the show.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_2: There is a very little time
solution:
Explanation:

‚ùå What's the error?

  • The phrase ‚Äúa very little time‚Äù is incorrect usage.

  • "Time" is an uncountable noun, so we do not use ‚Äúa very little‚Äù with it.

‚úÖ Correct Usage:

  • "very little time" ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct

  • "a little time" ‚Äì ‚úÖ Acceptable

  • ‚ùå "a very little time" ‚Äì Incorrect combination

So, the correct sentence should be:

‚ÄúThere is very little time for them to prepare for the show.‚Äù

Part of Speech Error:

Determiner usage ‚Äî incorrect article ("a") with uncountable noun ("time").

‚úîÔ∏è Final Answer: There is a very little time ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Athens was / a most luminous / of all city-states / of ancient Greece.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

‚ö†Ô∏è Error Explanation:

  • The phrase ‚Äúa most luminous‚Äù is grammatically incorrect in this context.

  • When comparing something as the best or most prominent among all, you must use the superlative form with ‚Äúthe‚Äù, not ‚Äúa‚Äù.

‚úÖ Correct Usage:

  • ‚ùå a most luminous of all city-states

  • ‚úÖ the most luminous of all city-states

üõ†Ô∏è Grammar Rule:

  • Use ‚Äúthe‚Äù + superlative adjective (most luminous, best, greatest) when referring to one out of all.

‚úÖ Corrected Sentence:

Athens was the most luminous of all city-states of ancient Greece.

‚úîÔ∏è Final Answer: a most luminous ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He bought a / pen; a / pen was silver / grey in colour.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
solution:
Answer: d) pen; a

Corrected sentence:
‚ÄúHe bought a pen; the pen was silver grey in colour.‚Äù

Explanation:

  • The second mention of ‚Äúpen‚Äù should use the definite article ‚Äúthe‚Äù because it refers to the specific pen already introduced in the first clause.

  • Using ‚Äúa‚Äù again incorrectly suggests a new, unspecified pen.

  • Therefore, the correct phrase is ‚Äúthe pen was silver grey in colour.‚Äù

  • The semicolon is acceptable here as it separates two independent clauses related to the same idea.

Hence, the error is in segment d) where ‚Äúa‚Äù should be replaced by ‚Äúthe.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
They missed their train / because they were waiting /on wrong platform. / They were on platform 3 instead of platform 8.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))

solution:

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase ‚Äúon wrong platform.‚Äù

  • The correct phrase should be ‚Äúon the wrong platform‚Äù because ‚Äúplatform‚Äù is a singular, countable noun and requires the definite article ‚Äúthe.‚Äù

Other parts are correct:

  • ‚ÄúBecause they were waiting‚Äù ‚Äì correct clause

  • ‚ÄúThey missed their train‚Äù ‚Äì correct clause

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
(1) Ravi walked / (2) up to a Principal‚Äôs cabin / (3) but could not meet him. / (4) No error

(SSC Steno 2023 : 13 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: (4) 2 - up to a Principal‚Äôs cabin

Explanation:

  • The error lies in the use of the article ‚Äúa‚Äù before ‚ÄúPrincipal‚Äôs‚Äù.

  • When using a possessive noun like ‚ÄúPrincipal‚Äôs cabin‚Äù, we refer to a specific person‚Äôs cabin, so the article should be ‚Äúthe‚Äù, not ‚Äúa‚Äù.

  • ‚úÖ Correct phrase: ‚Äúup to the Principal‚Äôs cabin‚Äù

Hence, the correct answer is (4).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
With cloud streaming, people can play games from a / internet-connected device, avoiding the need for pricey / dedicated hardware such as a game console.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-1)
option_2: internet-connected device, avoiding the need for pricey
option_3: With cloud streaming, people can play games from a
option_4: dedicated hardware such as a game console
solution:
The part that contains the error is: With cloud streaming, people can play games from a

The error is in the preposition used. It should be "on an internet-connected device" instead of "from a internet-connected device."

The corrected sentence would be: With cloud streaming, people can play games on an internet-connected device, avoiding the need for pricey dedicated hardware such as a game console.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The boy whose the sister is ill has left.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
he option that contains an error is "whose the sister."

Explanation: "Whose" is used as a possessive pronoun to indicate possession or relationship. In this case, it should be followed directly by the possessed object, so "whose sister" is correct.

The phrase "whose the sister" is incorrect, as it adds an unnecessary article ("the") before "sister."

The corrected sentence would be: "The boy whose sister is ill has left."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
After knowing truth, / the jury took the right decision / in the case.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 14 July Shift-2)
option_4: The jury took the right decision
solution:
Answer: After knowing truth

Solution:

  • The error lies in the phrase "After knowing truth".

  • In English, "truth" is a countable abstract noun that usually takes the definite article "the" when referring to a specific truth already known or being discussed.

  • The correct form should be: "After knowing the truth".

  • The rest of the sentence is grammatically correct.

Corrected sentence:
"After knowing the truth, the jury took the right decision in the case."

  • Truth means the actual facts ‚Äì ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à

  • The truth refers to specific or known truth ‚Äì ‡§µ‡§π ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§à (‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã ‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à)

So, the error is in Part 1: "After knowing truth".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
An lion is the most ferocious of all animals.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 14 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: An lion

Solution:

  • The error is in the phrase "An lion".

  • The article "an" is used before words that begin with a vowel sound, while "a" is used before consonant sounds.

  • Although "lion" begins with the vowel ‚Äòl‚Äô, it starts with a consonant sound, so the correct article is "a", not "an".

  • Therefore, it should be: "A lion is the most ferocious of all animals."

Other parts:

  • "is the most" ‚Äì correct comparative structure.

  • "ferocious of" ‚Äì part of the superlative phrase ‚Äúthe most ferocious of...‚Äù ‚Äì correct.

  • "all animals" ‚Äì grammatically correct.

So, the error is in: An lion.

question:

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift_1)
solution:
The option that contains an error is: "the England."

The correct way to express the idea is simply "to England" without the article "the." Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: "Ravi will go to England."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The cholera is a frightful disease.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
The correct part of the sentence is "The cholera."

The error is in the use of the article "The" before "cholera."

When referring to diseases, we typically use the article "a" or no article at all. Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: Cholera is a frightful disease.

In this corrected version, the article "The" has been removed before "cholera" to make the sentence grammatically accurate.

question:

So, it should be "a cheap dumping ground", not "an cheap...".
All other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
As noon approached, sunlight filtered/ through an branches, casting dappled/ patterns on the cobblestone path.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S1)
option_1: patterns on the cobblestone path.
option_3: through an branches, casting dappled
option_4: As noon approached, sunlight filtered
solution:
Explanation:

üîπ As noon approached, sunlight filtered ‚Äì ‚úÖ

This is grammatically correct.

"Filtered" is the correct past tense verb here.

üîπ through an branches, casting dappled ‚Äì ‚ùå (Error)

‚ö† Error Type: Article usage (Determiner)

‚öô Part of Speech Affected: Article + Noun

  • ‚ùå "an branches" is incorrect because "branches" is a plural noun.

  • ‚úîÔ∏è Correct usage: "through the branches" or "through some branches".

"An" is only used before singular, countable nouns starting with a vowel sound (e.g., an apple, an hour).

üîπ patterns on the cobblestone path. ‚Äì ‚úÖ

This is grammatically correct. ‚ÄúCasting dappled patterns‚Äù is a proper phrase.

üîß Correct Sentence:

As noon approached, sunlight filtered through the branches, casting dappled patterns on the cobblestone path.

question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
Start to relax a hour/ before bedtime with a/ hot bath or your favourite music.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S2)
option_3: hot bath or your favourite music.
option_4: Start to relax a hour
solution:
Explanataion:

üî¥ Incorrect Part:

"Start to relax a hour"

  • The article ‚Äúa‚Äù is used before words that begin with a consonant sound.

  • The article ‚Äúan‚Äù is used before words that begin with a vowel sound.

‚û°Ô∏è ‚ÄúHour‚Äù begins with a vowel sound (ow), even though it starts with the consonant letter ‚Äòh‚Äô (which is silent here).

‚úÖ Correct Usage:

‚ÄúStart to relax an hour‚Äù before bedtime...

üß† Rule Explained:

  • "a university" ‚úÖ (because "university" starts with a 'yoo' sound ‚Äî consonant)

  • "an hour" ‚úÖ (because "hour" starts with an ‚Äòow‚Äô sound ‚Äî vowel)

üÖæÔ∏è Other options are error-free:

  • before bedtime with a ‚Äì ‚úÖ grammatically correct.

  • hot bath or your favourite music. ‚Äì ‚úÖ parallel structure, no error.

  • No error ‚Äì ‚ùå incorrect answer because "a hour" is wrong.

üîÑ Final Sentence (Corrected):

Start to relax an hour before bedtime with a hot bath or your favourite music.

question:

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The / God / is / omniscient.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: (b) The

Explanation:

  • The sentence is: The / God / is / omniscient.

  • The error lies in ‚ÄúThe God‚Äù ‚Äî we do not use ‚Äúthe‚Äù before ‚ÄúGod‚Äù when referring to the supreme being in general religious or philosophical context.

Correct sentence: God is omniscient.
("God" here is used as a proper noun, so no article is required.)

However, since the options given are:

  • (a) is

The segment containing ‚ÄúThe‚Äù is (b), not (a). So this was likely a confusion.

question:

solution:

  • So, it should read: ‚ÄúArunima Sinha is the first amputee to scale Mount Everest.‚Äù

Therefore, part (d) contains the grammatical error.

question:

question:
The following sentence has been divided into three segments, A, B, C. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the segment that contains the error, from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Aniket lives (A) / in the small apartment (B) / in the suburbs (C).

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 18 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: B
Solution:

  • The sentence is: "Aniket lives (A) / in the small apartment (B) / in the suburbs (C)."

  • Segment B says: "in the small apartment", which is grammatically incorrect because ‚Äúthe small apartment‚Äù implies a specific one, but no prior reference is made to it.

  • It should be: "in a small apartment" ‚Äì using the indefinite article "a" to refer to any one small apartment.

  • Correct sentence: "Aniket lives in a small apartment in the suburbs."

  • ‚úÖ Therefore, the error is in segment B.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He is / able / to / play flute.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Answer: (d) play flute
Explanation: The phrase ‚Äúplay flute‚Äù is incorrect because in English we use the article ‚Äúthe‚Äù before musical instruments.
 The correct phrase is ‚Äúplay the flute.‚Äù
 Other parts:
 (a) able ‚Äì correct
 (b) He is ‚Äì correct
 (c) to ‚Äì correct
 ‚úÖ Hence, the correct answer is: (d) play flute.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I ate / the egg / yesterday for / my dinner.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-3)
solution:
Answer:the egg

Explanation:
 You're correct ‚Äî the grammatical issue lies in "the egg" in the context of the sentence.

The sentence is:
"I ate / the egg / yesterday for / my dinner."

  • While grammatically correct, saying "the egg" sounds awkward in this context.


  • In spoken and written English, we typically say:
     ‚úÖ "I ate eggs for dinner yesterday." (plural and without the article)
     or
     ‚úÖ "I ate an egg for dinner yesterday." (if referring to one egg)


So, the correct article should be "an" instead of "the", unless referencing a specific egg already mentioned.

Therefore, "the egg" is not the best usage here.

‚úÖ Corrected sentence:"I ate an egg yesterday for my dinner."
 ‚úÖ Correct answer:the egg

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Sky appears blue / as it absorbs / all colours and / reflects only blue.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 19 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: Sky appears blue
Solution:

  • The error is in the first segment "Sky appears blue" because it is missing the definite article "The" before "Sky."

  • Correct form: "The sky appears blue"

  • Proper use of articles is necessary in English grammar, especially before singular, countable nouns like "sky."

  • Other segments are grammatically correct.

‚úÖ Therefore, the segment containing the error is: Sky appears blue.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into three segments, A, B, C. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the segment that contains the error, from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It was (A) / by a chance (B) / he saw a movie in a theatre (C).

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 19 July Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: c) B
Solution:

  • The phrase "by a chance" is incorrect. The correct phrase is "by chance" (without the article "a").

  • "By chance" is an idiomatic expression meaning accidentally or unexpectedly.

  • So, the correct sentence should be: "It was by chance he saw a movie in a theatre."

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. One of them may contain an error. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Sunil refused to / attend the meeting / of association on Saturday.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: of association on Saturday

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Missing article

  • Part of speech affected: Noun phrase (‚Äúassociation‚Äù)

üìò Rule:

In English, singular countable nouns like ‚Äúassociation‚Äù require an article (a/an/the) before them when used in a sentence.

‚ùå ‚Äúof association‚Äù
‚úÖ ‚Äúof the association‚Äù

The definite article ‚Äúthe‚Äù is necessary because a specific association is being referred to.

üîÅ Correct sentence:

‚ÄúSunil refused to attend the meeting of the association on Saturday.‚Äù

‚ùå Evaluation of Other Segments:

  • Sunil refused to ‚Äì ‚úÖ
    ‚úî Grammatically correct (subject + verb + infinitive marker)

  • attend the meeting ‚Äì ‚úÖ
    ‚úî Proper verb usage; no error

  • of association on Saturday ‚Äì ‚ùå
    ‚úñ Missing article ‚Äúthe‚Äù before ‚Äúassociation‚Äù

  • No error ‚Äì ‚ùå
    ‚úñ Error present, so this can‚Äôt be correct

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúof association on Saturday‚Äù,which should be ‚Äúof the association on Saturday.‚Äù

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
He will return in a hour.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 21 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:(4) in a

Solution:
The error is in the phrase ‚Äúin a‚Äù. Since the word ‚Äúhour‚Äù begins with a vowel sound, the correct article should be ‚Äúan‚Äù, not ‚Äúa‚Äù.

Correct sentence:
He will return in an hour.

Rule:
Use ‚Äúan‚Äù before words that start with a vowel sound, even if the spelling begins with a consonant (like "hour").

question:

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 21 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:(4) for a opportunity

Solution:
The error lies in the use of the article ‚Äúa‚Äù before ‚Äúopportunity‚Äù.
Since ‚Äúopportunity‚Äù begins with a vowel sound, the correct article is ‚Äúan‚Äù, not ‚Äúa‚Äù.

Correct sentence:
She was waiting for an opportunity to start her own business.

Grammar Rule:
Use ‚Äúan‚Äù before words that begin with a vowel sound (a, e, i, o, u).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
After entering the town, / go straight and then / take a sharpest turn / towards your left / to reach the mall.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 24 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Answer: take a sharpest turn
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The phrase "a sharpest turn" is grammatically incorrect because it uses the indefinite article "a" with a superlative adjective "sharpest".
‚Ä¢ Superlative adjectives like "best," "biggest," "sharpest" are used with "the", not "a".

Correct phrase:
"take the sharpest turn"

Why the other parts are correct:
‚Ä¢ After entering the town ‚Äì grammatically correct introductory clause.
‚Ä¢ go straight and then ‚Äì proper sequence of directions.
‚Ä¢ towards your left ‚Äì correct prepositional phrase.
‚Ä¢ to reach the mall ‚Äì clearly expresses purpose.

question:

solution:

  • ‚ÄúAdventures‚Äù is plural, so it should not be preceded by ‚Äúan‚Äù (which is used for singular nouns).

  • Correct phrase: ‚Äúadventures of Tarzan‚Äù or ‚Äúan adventure of Tarzan.‚Äù

Correct sentence:
‚ÄúMaruti likes adventure stories, especially adventures of Tarzan.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Anti-party activities / improved my relations /with an opposition.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 25 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: With an opposition
Solution:

  • The error lies in ‚Äúwith an opposition‚Äù.

  • The word ‚Äúopposition‚Äù in this context is used as an uncountable noun, referring to the opposing political party in general. So, "an" before it is incorrect.

  • Correct phrase: ‚Äúwith the opposition‚Äù, not ‚Äúan opposition‚Äù.

  • Correct sentence: ‚ÄúAnti-party activities improved my relations with the opposition.‚Äù ‚úÖ

  • Article usage rule: Use "the" with specific or known singular groups like "the opposition", not "an".

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
She is in an hurry to meet her brother.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 26 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: an hurry
Solution:

  • The phrase ‚Äúan hurry‚Äù is incorrect because ‚Äúhurry‚Äù starts with a consonant sound /h/, so it should be preceded by the article ‚Äúa‚Äù instead of ‚Äúan‚Äù.

  • Correct phrase: ‚Äúa hurry‚Äù ‚úÖ

  • Correct sentence: ‚ÄúShe is in a hurry to meet her brother.‚Äù

question:

solution:

  • The correct article should be ‚Äúan‚Äù: ‚Äúsee an oculist‚Äù.

  • Correct sentence: ‚ÄúYou should see an oculist; your eyes look worse today.‚Äù ‚úÖ

question:

  • Correct phrase: ‚Äúis an honest‚Äù.

  • Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into three segments, A, B, C. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the segment that contains the error, from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He is not rich (A) / so he cannot afford (B) / to buy a expensive car (C).

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 27 July Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: c) C

  • The phrase is: "to buy a expensive car"

  • The error is in the article usage: we use "an" before words that start with a vowel sound

Rule:

  • Use ‚Äúa‚Äù before consonant sounds (e.g., a book, a car)

  • Use ‚Äúan‚Äù before vowel sounds (e.g., an apple, an honest man)

  • ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù starts with a vowel sound, so it should be: ‚Äúan expensive car‚Äù

Correct sentence:
He is not rich, so he cannot afford to buy an expensive car.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
They will not attend / the event / as they‚Äôre going / away at end of April.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_1: away at end of April.
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: away at end of April.

The corrected sentence would be: "They will not attend the event as they're going away at the end of April."

Explanation:

The error is in the placement of "the" in "at the end of April." The correct phrase should be "at the end of April" to indicate a specific point in time.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My apartment / in Delhi / is situated / on second floor.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: on second floor.

The phrase "on second floor" contains a grammatical error because, in English, when referring to the floor of a building, we use "the" before the ordinal number. The correct expression is "on the second floor."

The correct phrasing is "on the second floor." Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: "My apartment in Delhi is situated on the second floor."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
We should / not make an noise / in the class.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The error is in part B: "not make an noise." The article "an" should be "a" before the word "noise" because "noise" begins with a consonant sound, not a vowel sound.
So the corrected sentence would be: "We should not make a noise in the class."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error and select the option which rectifies that error.
AI fiction is a constantly / evolving genre that gives us an peek / into the potential upsides and downsides / of intelligent machines.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-1)
option_2: into a potential upside and downside
option_3: evolving genre that gives us a peek
option_4: AI fiction is an constantly
solution:
Answer: 3
Error segment: "evolving genre that gives us an peek"
Correction: "evolving genre that gives us a peek"

Explanation:

  • The article "an" is used before vowel sounds, but "peek" starts with a consonant sound, so "a peek" is correct.

  • The rest of the sentence is grammatically correct.

Corrected sentence:
AI fiction is a constantly evolving genre that gives us a peek into the potential upsides and downsides of intelligent machines.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error and select the option which rectifies that error.
A lot of adulterants / are chemicals that can lead / to an range of health problems / in both children and adults.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: are chemical that can lead
option_2: to a range of health problems
option_4: in both children and adult.
solution:
Answer: 2
Error segment: "to an range of health problems"
Correction: "to a range of health problems"

Explanation:

  • The article "an" is used before words that begin with a vowel sound, but "range" begins with a consonant sound, so the correct article is "a".

  • The rest of the sentence is correct.

Corrected sentence:
A lot of adulterants are chemicals that can lead to a range of health problems in both children and adults.
